daring this period reflects this mystical viewpoint.
In IB96, Yeats was attracted by the Irish Revolutionary movement and became
active in political life. With his friend Lady Gregory he founded the Irish
Literary Theatre and the Irish Academy, for which he wrote many plays. He
was acknowledged as the leader of the Irish literary renaissance which produced
Synge, Joyce, and others.
He married in 1917 and with his family settled on the Irish seacoast.
Retaining his interest in politics, he was for six years a member of the Irish
Senate. During this period Yeats was drawn to aysticism and was much criticised
for his outspoken views on this subject. He produced the finest writing of his
long career Airing this period and won the Ifobel Prise for literature in 1923.
Critics agree that he was one of the few poets whose later work was his best:
elaborate, symbolic, ornamental poetry of his youth developed into the austere,
objective, beautiful work of his old age.
IV. VOCABULARY NOTES
despair:
To be "thrown into despair" is a very serious situation. A complete
loss of hope and discouragement in the extreme are characteristic of this
state. As used in this poem, the phrase, describing a young man in love,
tore, has a lighter, less serious meaning and suggests the minor confusions
and disappointments characteristic of a romantic love affair.
ramparts:
The comparison «f Anne’s hair with military barricades suggests that her
yellow hair protects the girl fro® young men at the same time it attracts
them to her.
yellow:
Yellow is rather an unusual word to describe hair, particularly because
there are several special English words which describe this color of hair.
Blonde may be either adjective or noun (Blond is the masculine form of
thesame word); Fair-haired Fair, light or emven golden-haired are common.
Yellow, used to describe a woman’s hair, gives plesant, almost playful
spirit to the description/
